prior_works.title: 3D Gaussian Splatting for Real-Time Radiance Field Rendering
prior_works.authors: Bernhard Kerbl, Georgios Kopanas, Thomas Leimkühler, Wenzel Jakob
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the 3D Gaussian scene representation and the cloning/splitting-based densification and pruning heuristics that this paper reinterprets and replaces with principled MCMC state transitions.

prior_works.title: Bayesian Learning via Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the key algorithmic link that gradient-based parameter updates plus injected noise correspond to Langevin sampling, enabling the paper’s conversion of 3DGS optimization steps into SGLD updates.

prior_works.title: Stochastic Gradient Descent as Approximate Bayesian Inference
prior_works.authors: Philipp Mandt, Matthew D. Hoffman, David M. Blei
prior_works.role: Theory connecting SGD dynamics to posterior sampling
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Justifies viewing noisy gradient dynamics as sampling from an approximate posterior, underpinning the paper’s claim that injecting calibrated noise into 3DGS updates mitigates initialization sensitivity by exploring a distribution over scenes.

prior_works.title: Reversible Jump Markov Chain Monte Carlo Computation and Bayesian Model Determination
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes moves across variable-dimensional parameter spaces, directly inspiring the reinterpretation of densification (birth/split) and pruning (death/merge) of Gaussians as principled trans-dimensional state transitions.

prior_works.title: A Split-Merge Markov Chain Monte Carlo Procedure for the Dirichlet Process Mixture Model
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides concrete design of split/merge operations in mixture models that inform the paper’s replacement of ad hoc cloning with a relocalization (split/merge–like) transition for Gaussian components.

prior_works.title: A Complete Recipe for Stochastic Gradient MCMC
prior_works.authors: Yi-An Ma, Tianqi Chen, Emily B. Fox
prior_works.role: Design principles for SG-MCMC (noise, preconditioning, discretization)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Guides practical choices for noise injection, preconditioning, and discretization that make the paper’s SGLD-style updates for 3D Gaussian parameters stable and effective in high dimensions.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core innovation—recasting 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) as sampling from a scene distribution via Markov Chain Monte Carlo—stands on two pillars: the 3DGS representation and SG-MCMC theory. Kerbl et al. (2023) provided the core scene parameterization and the widely used cloning/splitting-based densification and pruning heuristics that enable real-time rendering but are initialization-sensitive and hand-engineered. The present work replaces those heuristics by interpreting the Gaussian set as samples from a latent scene distribution and by mapping standard 3DGS gradient updates to Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (Welling & Teh, 2011). This mapping is theoretically grounded by Mandt et al. (2017), which shows that noisy gradient dynamics approximate posterior sampling, thereby motivating calibrated noise injection to reduce dependence on initialization and to encourage exploration of better configurations.
Beyond turning optimization into sampling, the work must handle a variable number of Gaussians. Green’s Reversible Jump MCMC (1995) provides the trans-dimensional framework, directly inspiring a principled view of densification (birth/split) and pruning (death/merge) as state transitions in a single Markov chain. Jain & Neal’s split-merge MCMC (2004) for mixture models offers concrete analogs to cloning/splitting, guiding the paper’s relocalization move that substitutes heuristic cloning. Finally, Ma, Chen & Fox (2015) supply practical SG-MCMC design rules—noise calibration, preconditioning, and discretization stability—that underpin robust SGLD-style updates for high-dimensional Gaussian parameters. Together, these works enable a coherent probabilistic reinterpretation of 3DGS that removes ad hoc procedures while improving robustness.
